hiqfermion.utils package¶

Submodules¶

hiqfermion.utils.fenwick_tree module¶

A class to represent the Fenwicktree, which allows the compute sum and update operation to be performed in O(log n) times.

class hiqfermion.utils.fenwick_tree.FenwickNode(parent, children, index=None)¶

Bases: object

Represents Fenwick Tree node.

children = None¶
get_ancestors()¶

Returns a list of ancestors of the node. Ordered from the earliest.

Returns:
ancestor_list: A list of FenwickNodes.
index = None¶
parent = None¶
class hiqfermion.utils.fenwick_tree.FenwickTree(n_qubits)¶

Bases: object

Recursive implementation of the Fenwick tree.

Please see Subsection B.2. of Operator Locality in Quantum Simulation of Fermionic Models (arXiv:1701.07072) for a reference to the update set (U), the parity set (P) and the children set (F) sets of the Fenwick.

get_children_set(j)¶

Returns the set of children of j-th site.

Args:
j (int): Fermionic site index.
Returns:
A list of children of j. ordered from lowest index.
get_node(j)¶

Returns the node at j in the qubit register. Wrapper.

Args:
j (int): Fermionic site index.
Returns:
FenwickNode: the node at j.
get_parity_set(j)¶

Returns the union of the remainder set with children set. Coincides with the parity set of Tranter et al.

Args:
j (int): Fermionic site index.
Returns:
A C union F
get_remainder_set(j)¶

Return the set of children with indices less than j of all ancestors of j. The set C from (arXiv:1701.07072).

Args:
j (int): Fermionic site index.
Returns:
A list of children of j-ancestors with index less than j.
get_update_set(j)¶

The set of all ancestors of j, (the update set U from the paper).

Args:
j (int): Fermionic site index.
Returns:
List of ancestors of j, ordered from earliest.
root = None¶

hiqfermion.utils.generategroup module¶

hiqfermion.utils.generategroup.generate_parameter_group_for_parallel(x, num_threads)¶

Splite the parameter x into different groups for parallel tasks of num_threads threads.

Example: x=[‘a’,’c’,’d’,’e’] is the parameter for the parallel task. Now we need three parallel threads to solve this problem, we can split the parameters into three groups, such as x1=[‘a’,’c’],x2=[‘d’],x3=[‘e’]. The return is the begin and end index of the subgroup in the original parameters. In this example, the return should be [0,2,3,4]

hiqfermion.utils.generatejsonbypr module¶

hiqfermion.utils.generatejsonbypr.generate_json_by_pr(pr_file_name, pr_file_dir, to_name='plots.json')¶

hiqfermion.utils.graph_isomorphism module¶

The module used to judge if two graph isomorphism

examples:
graph_a = [['N', [0, 0.2, 0.2]],
                   ['H', [0.1, 0.2, 0.3]],
                   ['H', [0.3, 0.2, 0.1]],
                   ['H', [0.2, 0.1, 0.3]]]
graph_b = [['H', [0.1, 0.1, 0.2]],
                   ['H', [0.2, 0.2, 0.2]],
                   ['N', [0.2, 0.2, 0.2]],
                   ['H', [0.2, 0.3, 0.2]]]
print (compare_geometry(graph_a, graph_b))

The result of the example is False

Warning

This module does not support for chiral heterogeneity now.

hiqfermion.utils.graph_isomorphism.compare_geometry(grapha, graphb)¶

The main function for comparing two molecules

Args:
grapha(list):The sorted input graph like [[‘H’, [0, 0, 0]],[‘H’, [0, 1, 2]]] which includes all the molecular informations.
graphb(list):The sorted input graph like [[‘H’, [0, 0, 0]],[‘H’, [0, 1, 2]]] which includes all the molecular informations.
Returns:
is_isomorphism(Bool):
 True if isomorphism else False.

hiqfermion.utils.graph_isomorphism.rotation(graph, rx_theta=0.1, ry_theta=0.2, rz_theta=0.3)¶

Rotate a given graph by randomly choose the \(\theta\) for rotation

Args:
graph(list):The input graph like [[‘H’, [0, 0, 0]], [‘H’, [0, 1, 2]]] which includes all the molecular informations.
Returns:
graph(list):The graph after rotation.

hiqfermion.utils.paralleltask module¶

class hiqfermion.utils.paralleltask.ParallelTask(initial, task, post_processing, num_threads=1, use_ray=False)¶

Bases: object

Parallel execute the task. If you want to execute a quantum circuit with c++ backend, you’d better set “OMP_NUM_THREADS” to 1, that’s to say, execute “export OMP_NUM_THREADS=1” in you terminal.

run(x)¶

Async run the task. You can chose multiprocessing or ray to execute the parallel task. The post_processing function will be used to handle the result after the parallel task finished.

Args:
x: the parameters for the task that need to be parallelized.
set_fix_parameters(args_task, args_post_processing=None, same=True)¶

set the fix args for the task and post_processing, if “same” is True , than this two args will be set to same, otherwise, you shold specifice each of them.

Args:

args_task: fixed arguments for the task args_post_processing: fixed arguments for the post_processing same: if true, then you only need to set “args_task”, and the “args_post_processing”

will be the same with “args_task”, otherwise, you shold specifice both.

hiqfermion.utils.taylor_lcu_simulation module¶

This module is used to simulate the LCU type hamiltonian by taylor expansion.

class hiqfermion.utils.taylor_lcu_simulation.taylor_lcu(alpha, hl, t, uk)¶

Bases: object

Define all parts of lcu hamiltonian in a taylor decomposition.

Args:
alpha:The coefficients of lcu hamiltonian.
hl:The small matrices decomposed.
t:The simulation time.
uk:The taylor expansion length of U.
Example how to use:
 
from HiFermion.qubitization import *
new_taylor = taylor_lcu(alpha, hl, t, uk)
Example outputs:
 
exact_U = new_taylor.exactU
estimatedU = new_taylor.estimatedU
error = new_taylor.epsilon
hamiltonian = new_taylor.hamiltonian
beta()¶

Return the coefficients of decomposition of \(U\). Total number of terms \(m = \sum_{k = 0} ^ {K} L ^ k\).

error()¶

Input the \(U_{exact}\) and \(U_{estimated}\) and calculate the error \(\epsilon\) where

\[\epsilon = \sum(|U_{estimated} - U_{exact}|^2).\]
estimated_U()¶

Return the estimated value of \(U\). Known the values of alpha and \(H_l\).

exact_U()¶

Return the exact value of U matrix which \(U = e^{-iHt}\)

Warning

We can use the function expm from scipy.linlg only. The results from numpy is not correct in this situation.

hamiltonian_generator()¶

Generate a hamiltonian matrix by linear combination

Args:
alpha:An array of coefficients
Hl:A set of small matrix
Returns:

Hamiltonian matrix H
hiq_plugin()¶

Return the hiq code of taylor lcu hamiltonian simulation and do simulation on hiq.

Note

This part is under development.

matrix_P()¶

P is a projector matrix:

\[P = |0><0|\otimes I\]
vj()¶

Return the array contains all \(V_j\).

hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis module¶

Module to deal with reference state and basis transform.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.all_up_then_down(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Consider the order as all spin up then all spin down

hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.bravyi_kitaev_transform_matrix(n_qubits)¶
hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.get_bravyi_kitaev_basis_occupied_index(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

here we assume the spin is arranged up_down_up_down in this order, which is mostly in hartree fock product state.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.get_jordan_wigner_basis_occupied_index(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

here we assume the spin is arranged up_down_up_down in this order, which is mostly in hartree fock product state.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.get_occupied_index(n_qubits, n_electrons, fermion_transform='jordan_wigner')¶

Get the reference state occupied index under different transforms Args:

n_qubits(int): the qubits nubmer that to be simulated. Note this may changed in the bravyi_kitaev_tree_transform.
Returns:
a array with all the occupied index.
hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.get_parity_basis_occupied_index(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

here we assume the spin is arranged up_down_up_down in this order, which is mostly in hartree fock product state.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_basis.interleave_up_then_down(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Converting the spin order.From up-down-up-down-up-down-up-down to up-up-up-up-down-down-down-down

hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator module¶

hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.commutator(left_operator, right_operator)¶

Compute the commutator of two operators.

Args:
left_operator, right_operator: Operators in commutator. Any operators are accepted so long as implicit subtraction and multiplication are supported; e.g. QubitOperators, FermionOperators.
Raises:
TypeError: operator_a and operator_b are not of the same type.
hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.count_qubits(operator)¶

Calculate the number of qubits on which operator acts before prune the unused qubit

Args:
operator: FermionOperator or QubitOperator.
Returns:
num_qubits (int): The minimum number of qubits on which operator acts.
Raises:
TypeError: Operator of invalid type.

Note: in some case, we need to remove the unused index.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.down_index(index)¶

The index order, by default we set the spinless orbits as even-odd-even-odd (0,1,2,3,…)

hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.get_fermion_operator(operator)¶

Convert the tensor(Interaction operator)to FermionOperator.

Returns:
fermion_operator: An instance of the FermionOperator class.
hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.hermitian_conjugated(operator)¶

Return Hermitian conjugate of FermionOperator or QubitOperator.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.normal_ordered(fermion_operator)¶

Calculate and return the normal order of the FermionOperator. By convention, normal ordering implies terms are ordered from highest mode index (on left) to lowest (on right). Also, creation operators come first then follows the annihilation operator. e.g 3 4^ -> - 4^ 3

hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.normal_ordered_term(term, coefficient)¶
hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.number_operator(n_modes, mode=None, coefficient=1.0, parity=-1)¶

Return a fermionic number operator for the reverse_jordan_wigner transform.

Args:

n_modes (int): The number of modes in the system. mode (int, optional): The mode on which to return the number

operator. If None, return total number operator on all sites.

coefficient (float): The coefficient of the term. parity (int): Returns the fermionic number operator if parity=-1 (default),.

Returns:
operator (FermionOperator)
hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.sz_operator(n_spatial_orbitals)¶

Return the sz operator

Args:
n_spatial_orbitals(int): number of spatial orbitals (n_qubits // 2).
Returns:
operator (FermionOperator): corresponding to the sz operator over n_spatial_orbitals.
Note:
The default index order spin_up(alpha) corresponds to even index, while the spin_down(beta) corresponds to odd index
hiqfermion.utils.utils_operator.up_index(index)¶

The index order, by default we set the spinless orbits as even-odd-even-odd (0,1,2,3,…). The spin_up orbitals (alpha orbitals) with index even, while spin_down orbitals is (beta) with index odd.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_ucc module¶

Module to create and manipulate unitary coupled cluster operators.

hiqfermion.utils.utils_ucc.uccsd_evolution(fermion_generator, fermion_transform='jordan_wigner')¶

Create a ProjectQ evolution operator for a UCCSD circuit

Args:
fermion_generator(FermionOperator): UCCSD generator to evolve. fermion_transform: The transformation that defines the mapping from Fermions to QubitOperator.
Returns:
evoution_operator(TimeEvolution): The unitary operator
that constructs the UCCSD state.
hiqfermion.utils.utils_ucc.uccsd_singlet_evolution(packed_amplitudes, n_qubits, n_electrons, fermion_transform='jordan_wigner')¶

Create a ProjectQ evolution operator for a UCCSD singlet circuit

Args:
packed_amplitudes(ndarray): Compact array storing the unique single
and double excitation amplitudes for a singlet UCCSD operator. The ordering lists unique single excitations before double excitations.
n_qubits(int): Number of spin-orbitals used to represent the system,
which also corresponds to number of qubits in a non-compact map.

n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the physical system fermion_transform: The transformation that

defines the mapping from Fermions to QubitOperator.
Returns:
evoution_operator(TimeEvolution): The unitary operator
that constructs the UCCSD singlet state.
hiqfermion.utils.utils_ucc.uccsd_trotter_engine(compiler_backend=<projectq.backends._sim._simulator.Simulator object>, qubit_graph=None, opt_size=None)¶

Define a ProjectQ compiler engine that is common for use with UCCSD

This defines a ProjectQ compiler engine that decomposes time evolution gates using a first order Trotter decomposition on non-commuting gates down to a base gate decomposition.

Args:
compiler_backend(projectq.backend): Define the backend on the
circuit compiler, so that it may either simulate gates numerically or alternatively print a gate sequence, e.g. using projectq.backends.CommandPrinter()
qubit_graph(Graph): Graph object specifying connectivity of qubits.
The values of the nodes of this unique qubit ids. If None, all-to-all connectivity is assumed.
opt_size(int): Number for ProjectQ local optimizer to determine size
of blocks optimized over.
Returns:
projectq.cengine that is the compiler engine set up with these
rules and decompostions.
